Currently, this rate is applied to those who are completing recognised industry training involving at least 60 credits per year. |}
===Pakistan=== Monthly minimum wages in Pakistan are recommended by the Federal Government under nationally applicable Labour Policies and set by Provincial Minimum Wages Boards under the Minimum Wages Ordinance, 1961.
Pakistan's first minimum wage was introduced in 1992 when it was set at [[Pakistani rupee|PKR]] 1,500 (~[[United States dollar|US$]] 45) per month.
It was, subsequently, raised:
in 1996 to [[Pakistani rupee|PKR]] 1,650 (~[[United States dollar|US$]] 45.83) per month<br /> in 1998 to [[Pakistani rupee|PKR]] 1,950 (~[[United States dollar|US$]] 40.12) per month<ref>{{cite web|author=Bureau of International Labor Affairs |authorlink=United States Department of Labor |title=Pakistan Minimum Wage |publisher=U.S. Department of Labor |year=1998 |url=http://www.dol.gov/ilab/media/reports/oiea/wagestudy/FS-Pakistan.htm |accessdate=2006-12-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041223052238/http://www.dol.gov/ilab/media/reports/oiea/wagestudy/FS-Pakistan.htm |archivedate=December 23, 2004 }}</ref><br /> in 2001 to [[Pakistani rupee|PKR]] 2,500 (~[[United States dollar|US$]] $40.90) per month <ref>{{cite web | author = Mohammad Irfan | title = Pakistan's Wage Structure | year = 2008 | url = http://pide.org.pk/pdf/pws.pdf}}</ref> <br /> in 2003 to [[Pakistani rupee|PKR]] 3,000 (~[[United States dollar|US$]] $54.15) per month<br /> in 2004 to [[Pakistani rupee|PKR]] 4,000 (~[[United States dollar|US$]] $69.32) per month<br /> in 2007 to [[Pakistani rupee|PKR]] 4,600 (~[[United States dollar|US$]] $75.78) per month<br /> in 2008 to [[Pakistani rupee|PKR]] 6,000 (~[[United States dollar|US$]] $85.42) per month<br /> in 2010 to [[Pakistani rupee|PKR]] 7,000 (~[[United States dollar|US$]] $83.83) per month<ref>http://www.eobi.gov.pk/announcement/labour+poilcy+2010.pdf</ref><br /> in 2012 to [[Pakistani rupee|PKR]] 8,000 (~[[United States dollar|US$]] $86.39) per month<br /> in 2013 to [[Pakistani rupee|PKR]] 10,000 (~[[United States dollar|US$]] $102.56) per month<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/566389/minimum-wage-raised-to-rs10000-no-additional-tax-on-rs2-5-million-income/|title=Minimum wage raised to Rs10,000, no additional tax on Rs2.5 million income|author=|date=21 June 2013|work=The Express Tribune|accessdate=30 March 2016}}</ref><br /> in 2014 to [[Pakistani rupee|PKR]] 12,000 (~[[United States dollar|US$]] $124.10) per month<ref>{{cite web|last=Zaman |first=Qamar |url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/717183/minimum-wage-fixed-at-rs12000-up-by-rs2000/ |title=Minimum wage fixed at Rs12,000, up by Rs2,000 - The Express Tribune |publisher=Tribune.com.pk |date=2014-06-04 |accessdate=2016-03-30}}</ref>
(USD equivalents are calculated using the average annual exchange rate in the respective year)
===Romania=== {{Main|Minimum wage in Romania}} Two minimum wage levels are enforced in Romania. For state employees, the level is set by law at 600 RON (~US$200). For all other employees, the wage is set at 440RON (~US$145) by collective bargaining, which also stipulates multiplication indices for various levels of education. Jobs that require high-school and college qualifications are paid at least 1.5 and 2 times the minimum wage, respectively.<ref>{{cite web |author= |authorlink= |title=Cele doua salarii minime in vigoare bulverseaza autoritatile si angajatorii |publisher=Ziarul Financiar |date=2007-01-17 |url=http://www.zf.ro/articol_108065/cele_doua_salarii_minime_in_vigoare_bulverseaza_autoritatile_si_angajatorii.html |accessdate=2007-11-18 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070714141721/http://www.zf.ro/articol_108065/cele_doua_salarii_minime_in_vigoare_bulverseaza_autoritatile_si_angajatorii.html |archivedate=2007-07-14 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Teachers' unions resorted to justice to claim same treatment and be paid according to collective bargaining. As of November 2007, they won three landmark cases and expect similar decisions in several dozens other courts.<ref>{{cite web |author= |authorlink= |title=Salariile intelectualilor ar putea fi sacrificate pentru ale muncitorilor |publisher=Cotidianul |date=-01-07 |url=http://www2.cotidianul.ro/index.php?id=15411&art=38472&diraut=170&cHash=907b560173 |accessdate=2007-11-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071108221202/http://www.cotidianul.ro/index.php?id=15411 |archivedate=2007-11-08 |df= }}</ref> A single, unified level was proposed starting 1 January 2008 but it failed.<ref>{{cite web |author= |authorlink= |title=Salariul minim: 500 de lei pentru muncitori. Diploma se mai negociaza |publisher=Cotidianul |date=2007-11-14 |url=http://www2.cotidianul.ro/index.php?id=15596&art=38857&diraut=170&cHash=5ba9f6c69b |accessdate=2007-11-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071115170255/http://www.cotidianul.ro/index.php?id=15596 |archivedate=2007-11-15 |df= }}</ref>
=== Taiwan === {{Main|Minimum wage in Taiwan}} The Taiwanese government does not have a set minimum wage, but a basic wage in its Labor Standards Law serves the minimum wage function. The basic wage set per month is NT$22,000, NT$140 per hour, effective July 1, 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.taiwannews.com.tw/en/news/3523557 |accessdate=September 6, 2018}}</ref>
===United Kingdom=== {{Main|National Minimum Wage Act 1998}} Municipal regulation of wage levels began in some towns in 1524.
====Wages Councils==== The [[Trade Boards Act 1909]] created four Trades Boards that set minimum wages which varied between industries for a number of sectors where "sweating" <!-- Can anyone define that? --> was generally regarded as a problem and where collective bargaining was not well established. This system was extended considerably after the [[World War II|Second World War]]; in 1945 Trades Boards became Wages Councils, which set minimum wage standards in many sectors of the economy, including the service sector as well as manufacturing.<ref>[http://www.enotes.com/econ-encyclopedia/ wages-council ''Wages Council''] The Oxford Dictionary of Economics. Ed. John Black. Oxford University Press, 2002. eNotes.com. 2006. Retrieved on 6 Sep, 2008</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.statutelaw.gov.uk/content.aspx?LegType=All+Legislation&title=Wages+Act&Year=1986&searchEnacted=0&extentMatchOnly=0&confersPower=0&blanketAmendment=0&sortAlpha=0&TYPE=QS&PageNumber=1&NavFrom=0&parentActiveTextDocId=1543841&ActiveTextDocId=1543841&filesize=14267 |title=Wages Act 1986 (c. 48)|publisher=[[UK Ministry of Justice]]|work=[[UK Statute Law Database]]|accessdate=}}</ref> Wages Councils were finally abolished in 1993,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.emplaw.co.uk/researchfree-redirector.aspx?StartPage=data%2f026088.htm |title=Definitions and interpretation / wages order formerly WAGES ACT 1986 s.14 now REPEALED |publisher=[[Disclaw]] |accessdate=2008-09-06 }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> having fallen into decline due, in large part, to Trades Union opposition. A lower limit of pay, or "pay floor" was regarded as threatening the voluntary system of collective bargaining favoured in the UK. The government had first made a serious attempt to abolish Wages Councils in 1986, having abandoned existing legislation that tried to widen the scope of voluntary agreements to include those firms that had not taken part in negotiations, such as the Fair Wages Resolutions. These required that government contractors pay fair wages and respect the rights of their employees to be members of trades unions.
Instead the [[Wages Act 1986]] reformed the wages councils and abolished the power to create new ones.
====National Minimum Wage==== A National Minimum Wage (NMW) was introduced for the first time by the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] government on 1 April 1999 at the rate of [[Pound sterling|£]]3.60 per hour for those workers aged 22 and over,<ref name="uk">{{cite web|url=http://www.dti.gov.uk/employment/pay/national-minimum-wage/History-National-Minimum-Wage/page12572.html |last= |date=17 June 2006 |title=History of the National Minimum Wage |work=Employment Matters |publisher=United Kingdom [[Department of Trade and Industry (United Kingdom)|Department of Trade and Industry]] |accessdate=2006-06-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060619155233/http://www.dti.gov.uk/employment/pay/national-minimum-wage/History-National-Minimum-Wage/page12572.html |archivedate=19 June 2006 |df= }}</ref> Labour having promised to set a minimum wage in their [[United Kingdom general election, 1997|1997 general election]] campaign. In its election manifesto, it had claimed that every other modern industrial country had already adopted a minimum wage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.labour-party.org.uk/manifestos/1997/1997-labour-manifesto.shtml |title=Archived copy |accessdate=August 15, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080731030954/http://www.labour-party.org.uk/manifestos/1997/1997-labour-manifesto.shtml |archivedate=July 31, 2008 }}</ref>
This rate was set after the [[Low Pay Commission]] (LPC), an independent body the government appointed in July 1997 to advise it on low pay, recommended the rate.<ref>[http://www2.lowpay.gov.uk/lowpay/what_we_do.shtml ''What We Do''] Low Pay Commission</ref> The LPC's permanent status was later confirmed and it continues to make recommendations to government on the NMW, which has been uprated in October every year since 2000. The LPC board consists of nine members—three trade unionists, three employers, and three labour market relations experts. The Commission undertakes consultations each year to gather available evidence before making recommendations in its biennial review.
The current minimum wage in the UK, as of April 2018 is [[Pound sterling|£]]7.83 per hour for workers aged 25 and above, £7.38 for workers aged 21–24, £5.90 for workers aged 18–20, £4.20 for workers under 18, and £3.70 for apprentices aged 16–18 and those aged 19 or over who are in their first year.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.gov.uk/national-minimum-wage-rates | work=gov.uk | title=National Minimum Wage rates | date=2018-11-06}}</ref>
Some workers undertaking apprenticeships or accredited training may be exempted (that is, not considered eligible to receive the NMW) for a certain period of time, which varies according to their age and the length of time in employment. Other categories of worker who are exempt include [[au pair]]s, share fishermen, clergy, those in the [[British Armed Forces|Armed Forces]], prisoners and some people working in family businesses. The rate payable under the NMW can, in all cases, also be reduced where accommodation is provided to the worker.
Unlike most other employment rights legislation in the UK, which generally rely on affected individuals raising grievances and making claims, if necessary, before [[Employment tribunal|tribunals]] to enforce these rights, the NMW has compliance teams, attached to [[HMRC|Her Majesty's Revenue and Customs]] (HMRC) offices who will act on approaches from workers who think they are being paid less than the minimum wage by contacting and visiting their employers. Affected workers can either make a complaint directly to a national helpline or seek advice from another agencies such as their local [[Citizens Advice Bureau]] or the [[Scottish Low Pay Unit]]—this is particularly recommended if other employment rights issues are involved, as the HMRC can only deal with minimum wage enquiries.
====National Living Wage==== From 1 April 2016 a [[Living wage in the United Kingdom|National Living Wage]] was introduced for workers over 25, implemented at a significantly higher minimum wage rate, and expected to rise to at least £9 per hour by 2020.<ref>{{cite news|title=Third of British workers may benefit from new legal pay level|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/mar/30/third-of-british-workers-may-benefit-from-new-legal-pay-level|author=Larry Elliott|date=30 March 2016|newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref>
===United States=== {{Main|Minimum wage in the United States}} [[Image:History of US federal minimum wage increases.svg|thumb|300px|History of the federal minimum wage in real and nominal dollars in the United States.]] {{cquote|[[q:Franklin D. Roosevelt#Sourced|No business which depends for existence on paying less than living wages to its workers has any right to continue in this country.]]|author=[[President Franklin Delano Roosevelt]] |source=1933, [http://docs.fdrlibrary.marist.edu/odnirast.html Statement] on [[National Industrial Recovery Act]].<ref name="NYT-20140307">{{cite news |last=Tritch |first=Teresa |title=F.D.R. Makes the Case for the Minimum Wage |url=http://takingnote.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/03/07/f-d-r-makes-the-case-for-the-minimum-wage/ |date=March 7, 2014 |work=[[New York Times]] |accessdate=March 7, 2014 }}</ref>}} In the [[United States]], statutory minimum wages were first introduced nationally in 1938.<ref name="Sanjiv Sachdev 2003"/>
The [[Fair Minimum Wage Act of 2007]] is the current federal minimum wage law of the [[United States]]. It was signed into law on May 25, 2007<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/110/hr2206|title=U.S. Troop Readiness, Veterans’ Care, Katrina Recovery, and Iraq Accountability Appropriations Act, 2007 (2007; 110th Congress H.R. 2206) - GovTrack.us|author=|date=|work=GovTrack.us|accessdate=30 March 2016}}</ref> as a [[Rider (legislation)|rider]] to the [[U.S. Troop Readiness, Veterans' Care, Katrina Recovery, and Iraq Accountability Appropriations Act, 2007]]. The act implemented three increases to the federal minimum wage—from $5.15 an hour to $5.85 per hour on July 24, 2007, to $6.55 per hour on July 24, 2008, and to $7.25 an hour on July 24, 2009.<ref>{{cite news | work=The Library of Congress | title= Bill Summary and Status H.R. 2 |url=http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d110:HR00002:@@@D&summ2=m& |accessdate= August 10, 2010}}</ref>
Nearly all states within the [[United States]] have minimum wage laws; [[Alabama]], [[Louisiana]], [[Mississippi]], [[South Carolina]], and [[Tennessee]] are the only states yet to set a minimum wage law.<ref>[http://www.dol.gov/esa/minwage/america.htm DOL WHD: Minimum Wage Laws in the States<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070625194442/http://www.dol.gov/esa/minwage/america.htm |date=2007-06-25 }}</ref>
As of July 24, 2009, U.S. federal law requires a minimum wage of at least $7.25 per hour.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dol.gov/dol/topic/wages/minimumwage.htm|title=Minimum Wage|author=|date=|work=United States Department of Labor|accessdate=30 March 2016}}</ref> Just over 5% of all hourly-paid workers (or approximately 1% of the total U.S. population) earn an hourly wage at or below the minimum wage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bls.gov/cps/minwage2011.htm|title=Characteristics of Minimum Wage Workers: 2011|author=|date=2 March 2012|work=bls.gov|accessdate=30 March 2016}}</ref> [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]] has the highest minimum wage of any state in the U.S. at $9.19 per hour as of January 1, 2014;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dol.gov/whd/minwage/america.htm#Washington|title=Minimum Wage Laws in the States - Wage and Hour Division (WHD) - U.S. Department of Labor|author=|date=|work=dol.gov|accessdate=30 March 2016}}</ref> [[Oregon]] has the second highest at $9.10 per hour.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oregon.gov/boli/whd/docs/oregonminimumwage_eng_2014.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-01-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140307222711/http://www.oregon.gov/boli/whd/docs/oregonminimumwage_eng_2014.pdf |archivedate=2014-03-07 |df= }}</ref> Then [[Massachusetts]] with $9.00 per hour. The next highest state wage rates are in [[Connecticut]], [[Illinois]], [[Nevada]], and the [[District of Columbia]] at $8.25 per hour, and then [[Vermont]] at $8.06 per hour.<ref>[http://www.dol.gov/whd/minwage/america.htm consulted 19 January 2013.]</ref> In addition to federal and state minimum wage laws, the US also has citywide minimum wage laws ($14.00 in San Francisco).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sfgsa.org/index.aspx?page=411|title=Minimum Wage Ordinance (MWO)|author=|date=|work=sfgsa.org|accessdate=20 September 2017}}</ref>
According to the [[Economic Policy Institute]], the [[minimum wage]] in the United States would have been $18.28 in 2013 if the minimum wage kept pace with [[labor productivity]].<ref name="NYT-20140209">{{cite news |author=Editorial Board |title=The Case for a Higher Minimum Wage |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/09/opinion/sunday/the-case-for-a-higher-minimum-wage.html |date=February 9, 2014 |work=[[New York Times]] |accessdate=February 9, 2014 }}</ref> To adjust for increased rates of [[Productivity|worker productivity]] in the United States, raising the [[Minimum wage in the United States|minimum wage]] to $22 (or more) an hour has been presented.<ref name="WT-20130318">{{cite news |last=Chumley |first=Cheryl K. |title=Take it to the bank: Sen. Elizabeth Warren wants to raise minimum wage to $22 per hour |url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2013/mar/18/sen-elizabeth-warren-raise-minimum-wage-22-hour |date=March 18, 2013 |work=[[Washington Times]] |accessdate=January 22, 2014 }}</ref><ref name="HP-20130318">{{cite news |last=Wing |first=Nick |title=Elizabeth Warren: Minimum Wage Would Be $22 An Hour If It Had Kept Up With Productivity |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/03/18/elizabeth-warren-minimum-wage_n_2900984.html |date=March 18, 2013 |work=[[Huffington Post]] |accessdate=January 22, 2014 }}</ref><ref name="TSP-20131219">{{cite web |last=Hart-Landsberg, Ph.D. |first=Martin |title=$22.62/HR: The Minimum Wage If It Had Risen Like The Incomes Of The 1% |url=http://thesocietypages.org/socimages/2013/12/19/22-62hr-the-minimum-wage-if-it-had-risen-like-the-incomes-of-the-1/ |date=December 19, 2013 |work=thesocietypages.org |accessdate=January 22, 2014 }}</ref><ref name="POL-20131203">{{cite web |last=Rmusemore |first= |title=Stop Complaining Republicans, the Minimum Wage Should be $22.62 an Hour |url=http://www.politicususa.com/2013/12/03/stop-complaining-republicans-minimum-wage-22-62-hour.html |date=December 3, 2013 |work=policususa.com |accessdate=January 22, 2014 }}</ref>
===International Labour Organization=== [[International Labour Organization]] insists "minimum wage fixing" for rights of labours and has adopted [[Minimum Wage-Fixing Machinery Convention, 1928]], [[Minimum Wage Fixing Machinery (Agriculture) Convention, 1951]] and [[Minimum Wage Fixing Convention, 1970]] following up these former Conventions.
==See also== {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} * [[Average worker's wage]] * [[Economic inequality]] * [[Fair Labor Standards Act]] * [[List of minimum wages by country]] * [[List of U.S. minimum wages]] * [[Living wage]] * [[Maximum wage]] {{col-2}} * [[Minimum wage]] * [[Minimum Wage Fixing Convention, 1970]] * [[Minimum wage in the United States]] * [[United States labor law]] * [[Wage slavery]] * [[Working poor]] {{col-end}}

{{Infobox podcast | title = Probably Science | image = <!-- Image.ext without File: or Image: --> | image_size = | alt = | caption = <!-- Caption for the image (if needed) --> | hosting = [[Andy Wood (comedian)|Andy Wood]], [[Matt Kirshen]], and Jesse Case | starring = | genre = Comedy, science | format = | creator = | developer = | writer = | director = | creative_director = | voices = | narrated = | judges = | language = [[English language|English]] | language_other = <!-- If the podcast also made in other languages, list here --> | updates = <!-- or 'status' --> | length = | camera = <!-- For camerawork credits --> | direction = <!-- For direction credits --> | production = <!-- For production credits --> | preceded_by = | theme_music_composer = | opentheme = | endtheme = | composer = | motion_graphics = | picture_format = | video format = | audio format = | num_seasons = | num_episodes = <!-- actual number of episodes, if known --> | list_episodes = <!-- Wikipedia "List of" article (( don't include [[ ]]).--> | began = January 21, 2012 | ended = <!-- or 'final'; date of last airing (if applicable) --> | ratings = | cited_for = <!-- Any awards, --> | cited_as = <!-- honors, recognitions, etc. --> | provider = <!-- or 'network'; Media provider or network e.g. BBC, Revision 3, etc.--> | license = <!-- License under which podcast falls --> | related_shows = | website = http://www.probablyscience.com/ | misc = <!-- Audio file using syntax: [[File:recording_name.extension]]. --> <!-- Or video files, with the extension "ogv". --> | audio caption = <!-- Caption for the audio recording--> | module = }}
'''''Probably Science''''' is a weekly updated comedy and science [[podcast]] which first aired on January 21, 2012. The show is co-hosted by [[Andy Wood (comedian)|Andy Wood]], [[Matt Kirshen]], and Jesse Case. Former co-host and founding member [[Brooks Wheelan]] having left the show in 2013 for personal reasons<ref>{{cite web|url=http://probablyscience.libsyn.com/episode-154-brooks-wheelan-returns|title=Probably Science : Episode 154 - Brooks Wheelan Returns|work=libsyn.com}}</ref> and has since returned as a guest. In Brooks's absence, Case, previously a guest, was brought on as a co-host.
The podcast focuses on current scientific news. Occasionally it explores different facets of relevant media, including the host's comedy careers, as well as the large array of careers and hobbies held by the guests.
A wide range of guest have appeared in their episodes, including astronaut [[Chris Hadfield]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://probablyscience.libsyn.com/episode-134-astronaut-and-former-commander-of-the-iss-colonel-chris-hadfield|title=Probably Science : Episode 134 - Astronaut and Former Commander of the ISS Colonel Chris Hadfield|work=libsyn.com}}</ref> astrophysicist [[Neil deGrasse Tyson]],<ref>{{cite web| url=https://probablyscience.libsyn.com/episode-249-neil-degrasse-tyson |title=Episode 249 - Neil deGrasse Tyson |work=libsyn.com}}</ref> comedian [[Chris Hardwick]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://probablyscience.libsyn.com/episode-061-the-nerdist-s-chris-hardwick|title=Probably Science : Episode 061 - The Nerdist's Chris Hardwick|work=libsyn.com}}</ref> [[Sean M. Carroll]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://probablyscience.libsyn.com/episode-078-dr-sean-carroll|title=Probably Science : Episode 078 - Dr. Sean Carroll|work=libsyn.com}}</ref> (a research professor in the Department of Physics at the California Institute of Technology), and two appearances from ''[[Doctor Who]]'' and ''[[Guardians of the Galaxy (film)|Guardians of the Galaxy]]'' actress [[Karen Gillan]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.probablyscience.com/probablyscience/episode-86-with-karen-gillan|title=Probably Science : Episode 086 - Karen Gillan}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.probablyscience.com/probablyscience/2014/1/31/episode-100-with-karen-gillan-bonus-brooks-wheelan-and-greatest-hits|title=Probably Science : Episode 100 with Karen Gillan bonus Brooks Wheelan and greatest hits}}</ref>
== Notable mentions== ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'': Fun Podcasts for the Science-Minded<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archive.wired.com/geekmom/2013/01/top-science-podcasts/|title=Fun Podcasts for the Science-Minded|work=GeekMom}}</ref>
''[[The A.V. Club]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/detail/miranda-july-nerds-out-while-david-cross-and-jon-h-214585|title=Miranda July nerds out, while David Cross and Jon Hamm laugh it up|work=avclub.com}}</ref>
''[[Splitsider]]'': This week in Comedy podcast.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://splitsider.com/2012/02/this-week-in-comedy-podcasts-40/|title=This Week in Comedy Podcasts - Splitsider|work=Splitsider}}</ref>

{{about|[[knowledge]] derived from the [[scientific method]]|its usage in expert witnessing|Scientific evidence (law)}}
'''Scientific evidence''' is [[evidence]] which serves to either support or counter a [[science|scientific]] [[Scientific theory|theory]] or [[hypothesis]]. Such evidence is expected to be [[empirical evidence]] and interpretation in accordance with [[scientific method]]. Standards for scientific evidence vary according to the field of inquiry, but the strength of scientific evidence is generally based on the results of [[Statistics|statistical analysis]] and the strength of [[scientific control]]s.
==Principles of inference ==
A person's assumptions or beliefs about the relationship between observations and a hypothesis will affect whether that person takes the observations as evidence.<ref name="philsci">{{cite book|last=Longino|first=Helen|title=Philosophy of Science, Vol. 46|date=March 1979|pages=37–42}}</ref> These assumptions or beliefs will also affect how a person utilizes the observations as evidence. For example, the Earth's apparent lack of motion may be taken as evidence for a geocentric cosmology. However, after sufficient evidence is presented for heliocentric cosmology and the apparent lack of motion is explained, the initial observation is strongly discounted as evidence.
When rational observers have different background beliefs, they may draw different conclusions from the same scientific evidence. For example, [[Joseph Priestley|Priestley]], working with [[phlogiston theory]], explained his observations about the decomposition of [[mercuric oxide]] using phlogiston. In contrast, [[Antoine Lavoisier|Lavoisier]], developing the theory of elements, explained the same observations with reference to oxygen.<ref name = "Kuhn">Thomas S. Kuhn, The Structure of Scientific Revolution, 2nd Ed. (1970).</ref> Note that a causal relationship between the observations and hypothesis does not exist to cause the observation to be taken as evidence,<ref name="philsci"/> but rather the causal relationship is provided by the person seeking to establish observations as evidence.
A more formal method to characterize the effect of background beliefs is [[Bayesian inference]].<ref>[http://plato.stanford.edu/archives/spr2007/entries/epistemology-bayesian/ William Talbott "Bayesian Epistemology"] Accessed May 13, 2007.</ref> In Bayesian inference, beliefs are expressed as percentages indicating one's confidence in them. One starts from an initial probability (a [[Prior probability|prior]]), and then updates that probability using [[Bayes' theorem]] after observing evidence.<ref>[http://plato.stanford.edu/archives/spr2007/entries/evidence/ Thomas Kelly "Evidence"]. Accessed May 13, 2007.</ref> As a result, two independent observers of the same event will rationally arrive at different conclusions if their priors (previous observations that are also relevant to the conclusion) differ. However, if they are allowed to communicate with each other, they will end in agreement (per [[Aumann's agreement theorem]]).
The importance of background beliefs in the determination of what observations are evidence can be illustrated using [[deductive reasoning]], such as [[syllogism]]s.<ref>George Kenneth Stone, "Evidence in Science"(1966)</ref> If either of the propositions is not accepted as true, the conclusion will not be accepted either.
==Utility of scientific evidence==
{{see also|Falsifiability}}
Philosophers, such as [[Karl R. Popper]], have provided influential theories of the [[scientific method]] within which scientific evidence plays a central role.<ref>Karl R. Popper,"The Logic of Scientific Discovery" (1959).</ref> In summary, Popper provides that a scientist creatively develops a theory which may be falsified by testing the theory against evidence or known facts. Popper's theory presents an asymmetry in that evidence can prove a theory wrong, by establishing facts that are inconsistent with the theory. In contrast, evidence cannot prove a theory correct because other evidence, yet to be discovered, may exist that is inconsistent with the theory.<ref>[http://www.fjc.gov/public/pdf.nsf/lookup/sciman00.pdf/$file/sciman00.pdf Reference Manual on Scientific Evidence], 2nd Ed. (2000), p. 71. Accessed May 13, 2007.(dead link) see: [https://www.fjc.gov/sites/default/files/2015/SciMan3D01.pdf the 3rd edition of Reference Manual on Scientific Evidence]</ref>
==Philosophic versus scientific views==
The philosophical community has investigated the logical requirements for scientific evidence by examination of the relationship between evidence and hypotheses, in contrast to scientific approaches which focus on the candidate facts and their context.<ref>Deborah G. Mayo, Philosophy of Science, Vol. 67, Supplement. Proceedings of the 1998 Biennial Meetings of the [[Philosophy of Science Association]]. Part II: Symposia Papers. (Sep., 2000), pp. S194.</ref> [[William Bechtel|Bechtel]], as an example of a scientific approach, provides factors (clarity of the data, replication by others, consistency with results arrived at by alternative methods and consistency with plausible theories) useful for determination of whether observations may be considered scientific evidence.<ref>William Bechtel, Scientific Evidence: Creating and Evaluating Experimental Instruments and Research Techniques, PSA: Proceedings of the Biennial Meeting of the Philosophy of Science Association, Vol. 1 (1990) p. 561.</ref>
There are a variety of philosophical approaches to decide whether an observation may be considered evidence; many of these focus on the relationship between the evidence and the hypothesis. Carnap recommends distinguishing such approaches into three categories: classificatory (whether the evidence confirms the hypothesis), comparative (whether the evidence supports a first hypothesis more than an alternative hypothesis) or quantitative (the degree to which the evidence supports a hypothesis).<ref>Rudolf Carnap, Logical Foundations of Probability (1962) p. 462.</ref> [[Peter Achinstein|Achinstein]] provides a concise presentation by prominent philosophers on evidence, including [[Carl Hempel]] (Confirmation), [[Nelson Goodman]] (of grue fame), [[R. B. Braithwaite]], [[Norwood Russell Hanson]], [[Wesley C. Salmon]], Clark Glymour and [[Rudolf Carnap]].<ref>Peter Achinstein (Ed.) "The Concept of Evidence" (1983).</ref>
Based on the philosophical assumption of the [[Church–Turing thesis#Philosophical implications|Strong Church-Turing Universe Thesis]], a mathematical criterion for evaluation of evidence has been conjectured, with the criterion having a resemblance to the idea of [[Occam's Razor]] that the simplest comprehensive description of the evidence is most likely correct. It states formally, "The ideal principle states that the prior probability associated with the hypothesis should be given by the algorithmic universal probability, and the sum of the log universal probability of the model plus the log of the probability of the data given the model should be minimized."<ref>Paul M. B. Vitányi and Ming Li; "Minimum Description Length Induction, Bayesianism and Kolmogorov Complexity".</ref>
According to the posted curriculum for an [http://undsci.berkeley.edu/article/0_0_0/howscienceworks_06 "Understanding Science 101"] course taught at University of California - Berkeley: "Testing hypotheses and theories is at the core of the process of science." This philosophical belief in "hypothesis testing" as the essence of science is prevalent among both scientists and philosophers. It is important to note that this [[hypothesis]] does not take into account all of the activities or scientific objectives of all scientists. When Geiger and Marsden [[Geiger–Marsden experiment| scattered alpha particles through thin gold foil]] for example, the resulting data enabled their experimental adviser, Ernest Rutherford, to very accurately calculate the mass and size of an atomic nucleus for the first time. No hypothesis was required. It may be that a more general view of science is offered by physicist, Lawrence Krauss, who consistently writes in the [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/lawrence-m-krauss/the-big-unanswered-questi_1_b_7151666.html media] about scientists answering questions by measuring physical properties and processes.
== Concept of scientific proof == While the phrase "scientific proof" is often used in the popular media,<ref>See, for example, {{cite web | url=http://www.foxnews.com/science/2014/02/26/greenpeace-co-founder-no-scientific-proof-humans-are-dominant-cause-warming/ | title=Greenpeace co-founder: No scientific proof humans are dominant cause of warming climate | work=[[Fox News Channel]] | date=28 February 2014 | accessdate=19 March 2014}}</ref> many scientists have argued that there is really no such thing. For example, [[Karl Popper]] once wrote that "In the empirical sciences, which alone can furnish us with information about the world we live in, proofs do not occur, if we mean by 'proof' an argument which establishes once and for ever the truth of a theory".<ref>{{cite book |last=Popper |first=Karl |date=2011 |orig-year=1966 |title=[[The Open Society and Its Enemies]] |edition=5th |location= |publisher=Routledge |pages=229-230 |isbn=9781136700323 |author-link=Karl Popper }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.talkorigins.org/faqs/comdesc/sciproof.html | title=29+ Evidences for Macroevolution | work=[[TalkOrigins Archive]] | date=1999–2012 | accessdate=19 March 2014 | author=Theobald, Douglas}}</ref> Albert Einstein said:
{{block quote|The scientific theorist is not to be envied. For Nature, or more precisely experiment, is an inexorable and not very friendly judge of his work. It never says "Yes" to a theory. In the most favorable cases it says "Maybe," and in the great majority of cases simply "No." If an experiment agrees with a theory it means for the latter "Maybe," and if it does not agree it means "No." Probably every theory will someday experience its "No" - most theories, soon after conception.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Gaither|first1=Carl|title=Gaither's Dictionary of Scientific Quotations|date=2009|publisher=Springer|location=New York, NY|isbn=978-0-387-49575-0|page=1602}}</ref>}}

{{distinguish|Superfluidity|Subcooling}}
'''Supercooling''', also known as '''undercooling''',<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Rathz |first=Tom |title=Undercooling |url=https://science.nasa.gov/ssl/msad/dtf/under1.htm |accessdate=2010-01-12 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5mjJauR7S?url=http://science.nasa.gov/ssl/msad/dtf/under1.htm |archivedate=2010-01-12 |postscript=. |publisher=[[NASA]] |ref=harv |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> is the process of lowering the temperature of a [[liquid]] or a [[gas]] below its [[melting point|freezing point]] without it becoming a [[solid]].
==Explanation== A liquid crossing its standard freezing point will [[crystalization|crystalize]] in the presence of a [[nucleation|seed crystal or nucleus]] around which a [[crystal]] structure can form creating a solid. Lacking any such [[seed crystal|nuclei]], the liquid [[phase (matter)|phase]] can be maintained all the way down to the temperature at which [[nucleation#Homogeneous nucleation|crystal homogeneous nucleation]] occurs. Homogeneous nucleation can occur above the [[glass transition temperature]], but if homogeneous nucleation has not occurred above that temperature, an [[amorphous]] (non-crystalline) solid will form.
[[Water]] normally freezes at 273.15 [[Kelvin|K]] (0 °C or 32 °F), but it can be "supercooled" at [[standard pressure]] down to its [[nucleation#Homogeneous nucleation|crystal homogeneous nucleation]] at almost 224.8 K (−48.3 °C/−55 °F).<ref>{{cite journal|last=Moore|first=Emily|author2=Valeria Molinero |title=structural transformation in supercooled water controls the crystallization rate of ice|journal=Nature|date=24 November 2011|volume=479|issue=7374|pages=506–508|doi=10.1038/nature10586|arxiv = 1107.1622 |bibcode = 2011Natur.479..506M|pmid=22113691}}</ref><ref name="debenedetti 42">{{harvnb|Debenedetti|Stanley|2003|p=42}}</ref> The process of supercooling requires that water be pure and free of [[nucleation]] sites, which can be achieved by processes like [[reverse osmosis]] or [[chemical demineralization]], but the cooling itself does not require any specialised technique. If water is cooled at a rate on the order of 10<sup>6</sup> K/s, the crystal nucleation can be avoided and water becomes a [[Glass#Physical properties|glass]]—that is, an amorphous (non-crystalline) solid. Its [[glass transition temperature]] is much colder and harder to determine, but studies estimate it at about 136 K (−137 °C/−215 °F).<ref>Insights into Phases of Liquid Water from Study of Its Unusual Glass-Forming Properties, C. Austen Angell, Science 319, 582 (2008);[http://www.sciencemag.org/content/319/5863/582.full.pdf] [http://phys.org/news121010887.html].</ref> [[Amorphous ice|Glassy water]] can be heated up to approximately 150 K (−123 °C/−189.4 °F) without nucleation occurring.<ref name="debenedetti 42"/> In the range of temperatures between 231 K (−42 °C/−43.6 °F) and 150 K (−123 °C/−189.4 °F), experiments find only crystal ice.
Droplets of supercooled water often exist in [[stratus]] and [[cumulus]] [[cloud]]s. An [[aircraft]] flying through such a cloud sees an abrupt crystallization of these droplets, which can result in the formation of ice on the aircraft's wings or blockage of its instruments and probes, unless the aircraft is equipped with an appropriate [[de-icing]] system. [[Freezing rain]] is also caused by supercooled droplets.
The process opposite to supercooling, the melting of a solid above the freezing point, is much more difficult, and a solid will almost always melt at the same [[temperature]] for a given [[pressure]]. For this reason, it is the melting point which is usually identified, using [[melting point apparatus]]; even when the subject of a paper is "freezing-point determination", the actual methodology is "the principle of observing the disappearance rather than the formation of ice".<ref>"[http://jeb.biologists.org/cgi/reprint/26/1/57.pdf A new method of freezing-point determination for small quantities]", J. A. Ramsay, ''[[J. Exp. Biol.]]''.1949; 26</ref> It is possible, at a given pressure, to [[superheating|superheat]] a liquid above its [[boiling point]] without it becoming gaseous.
Supercooling is often confused with [[freezing-point depression]]. Supercooling is the cooling of a liquid below its freezing point without it becoming solid. Freezing point depression is when a [[solution]] can be cooled below the freezing point of the corresponding pure liquid due to the presence of the [[Solution|solute]]; an example of this is the freezing point depression that occurs when [[sodium chloride]] is added to pure water.
== Constitutional supercooling == [[File:Constitutional supercooling - phase diagram, concentration, and temperature.png|thumb|Constitutional supercooling – phase diagram, concentration, and temperature]]
Constitutional supercooling, which occurs during solidification, is due to compositional solid changes, and results in cooling a liquid below the freezing point ahead of the [[solid–liquid interface]]. When solidifying a liquid, the interface is often unstable, and the velocity of the solid–liquid interface must be small in order to avoid constitutional supercooling.
Supercooled zones are observed when the [[liquidus]] temperature gradient at the interface is larger than the temperature gradient.
: <math>\left.\frac{\partial T_L}{\partial x}\right|_{x=0} > \frac{\partial T}{\partial x}</math>
or
: <math>m \left.\frac{\partial C_L}{\partial x}\right|_{x=0} > \frac{\partial T}{\partial x}</math>
The slope of the liquidus phase boundary on the phase diagram is <math>m = \partial T_L / \partial C_L</math>
The concentration gradient is related to points, <math>C^{LS}</math> and <math>C^{SL}</math>, on the phase diagram:
: <math>\left.\frac{\partial C_L}{\partial x}\right|_{x=0} = - \frac{C^{LS} - C^{SL}}{D/v}</math>
For steady-state growth <math>C^{SL}=C_0</math> and the partition function <math>k=\frac{C^{SL}}{C^{LS}}</math> can be assumed to be constant. Therefore, the minimum thermal gradient necessary to create a stable solid front is as expressed below.
: <math>\frac{\partial T}{\partial x} < \frac{m C_0 (1-k) v}{kD}</math>
For more information, see the equation (3) of<ref>[http://chem.wzu.edu.cn/UploadFile/20094315104316.pdf#page=99 page from 99~100] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130729120202/http://chem.wzu.edu.cn/UploadFile/20094315104316.pdf#page=99 |date=July 29, 2013 }}</ref>
==In animals==
In order to survive extreme low temperatures in certain environments, some animals use the phenomenon of supercooling that allow them to remain unfrozen and avoid cell damage and death. There are many techniques that aid in maintaining a liquid state, such as the production of [[antifreeze protein]]s, or AFPs, which bind to ice crystals to prevent water molecules from binding and spreading the growth of ice.<ref>{{cite journal |author=J.G. Duman|title=Antifreeze and ice nucleator proteins in terrestrial arthropods|journal=Annual Review of Physiology|volume=63|pages=327–357|year=2001|doi=10.1146/annurev.physiol.63.1.327|pmid=11181959}}</ref> The [[winter flounder]] is one such fish that utilizes these proteins to survive in its frigid environment. Noncolligative proteins are secreted by the liver into the bloodstream.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Garth L Fletcher |author2=Choy L Hew |author3=Peter L Davies |last-author-amp=yes |title=Antifreeze Proteins of Teleost Fishes|journal=Annual Review of Physiology|volume=63|pages=359–390|year=2001|doi= 10.1146/annurev.physiol.63.1.359|pmid=11181960}}</ref> Other animals use colligative antifreezes, which increases the concentration of solutes in their bodily fluids, thus lowering their freezing point. Fish that rely on supercooling for survival must also live well below the water surface, because if they came into contact with ice nuclei they would freeze immediately. Animals that undergo supercooling to survive must also remove ice-nucleating agents from their bodies because they act as a starting point for freezing. Supercooling is also common in insects, reptiles, and other [[ectotherm]]s, with insects being able to survive in the coldest environments out of any supercooling animals.
Supercooling is a last resort for animals. The best option is to move to a warmer environment if possible. As an animal gets farther and farther below its original freezing point the chance of spontaneous freezing increases dramatically for its internal fluids, as this is a thermodynamically unstable state. The fluids eventually reach the supercooling point, which is the temperature at which the supercooled solution freezes spontaneously due to being so far below its normal freezing point.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=C.H. Lowe |author2=P.J. Lardner |author3=E.A. Halpern |last-author-amp=yes |title=Supercooling in reptiles and other vertebrates|journal=Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology|volume=39A|issue=1|pages=125–135|year=1971|doi=10.1016/0300-9629(71)90352-5|pmid=4399229}}</ref> Animals unintentionally undergo supercooling and are only able to decrease the odds of freezing once supercooled. Even though supercooling is essential for survival, there are many risks associated with it.
==In plants== As demonstrated by animals, plants can also survive extreme cold conditions brought forth during the winter months. Many plant species located in northern climates can acclimate under these cold conditions by supercooling, thus these plants survive temperatures up to −40 °C. Although this supercooling phenomenon is poorly understood, it has been recognized through [[infrared thermography]]. Ice nucleation occurs in certain plant organs and tissues, debatably beginning in the [[xylem]] tissue and spreading throughout the rest of the plant.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite journal|last1=Wisniewski|first1=M|title=Observations of ice nucleation and propagation in plants using infrared thermography|journal=Plant Physiology|date=1997|volume=113|issue=2|pages=327–334|doi=10.1104/pp.113.2.327|pmid=12223611|pmc=158146}}</ref><ref name="Pearce2001">{{cite journal|last1=Pearce|first1=R|title=Plant freezing and damage|journal=Analysis of Botany|date=2001|volume=87|issue=4|pages=417–424|url=http://aob.oxfordjournals.org/content/87/4/417.full.pdf|accessdate=11 December 2016|doi=10.1006/anbo.2000.1352}}</ref> Infrared thermography allows for droplets of water to be visualized as they crystalize in extracellular spaces.<ref name="tandfonline.com">{{cite journal|last1=Wisniewski|first1=M|title=Ice nucleation, propagation, and deep supercooling in woody plants|journal=Journal of Crop Improvement|date=2004|volume=10|pages=5–16|doi=10.1300/j411v10n01_02}}</ref>
Supercooling inhibits the formation of ice within the tissue by ice nucleation and allows the cells to maintain water in a liquid state and further allows the water within the cell to stay separate from extracellular ice.<ref name="tandfonline.com"/> Cellular barriers such as [[lignin]], [[suberin]] and the cuticle inhibit ice nucleators and force water into the supercooled tissue.<ref name="journals.plos.org">{{cite journal|last1=Kuprian|first1=E|title=Persistent supercooling of reproductive shoots is enabled by structural ice barriers being active despite intact xylem connection|journal=PLOS ONE|volume=11|issue=9|page=e0163160|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0163160|pmid=27632365|pmc=5025027|bibcode=2016PLoSO..1163160K|year=2016}}</ref> The xylem and primary tissue of plants are very susceptible to cold temperatures because of the large proportion of water in the cell. Many boreal hardwood species in northern climates have the ability to prevent ice spreading into the shoots allowing the plant to tolerate the cold.<ref name="ncbi.nlm.nih.gov">{{cite journal|last1=Neuner|first1=Gilbert|title=Frost resistance in alpine woody plants|journal=Front Plant Sci|date=2014|volume=5|page=654|doi=10.3389/fpls.2014.00654|pmid=25520725|pmc=4249714}}</ref> Supercooling has been identified in the evergreen shrubs ''[[Rhododendron ferrugineum]]'' and ''[[Vaccinium vitis-idaea]]'' as well as ''[[Abies]]'', ''[[Picea]]'' and ''[[Larix]]'' species.<ref name="ncbi.nlm.nih.gov"/> Freezing outside of the cell and within the cell wall does not affect the survival of the plant.<ref name="Freezing and injury in plants">{{cite journal|last1=Burke|first1=M|title=Freezing and injury in plants|journal=Annual Review of Plant Physiology|date=1976|volume=27|pages=507–528|doi=10.1146/annurev.pp.27.060176.002451}}</ref> However, the extracellular ice may lead to plant dehydration.<ref name="Pearce2001"/>
==Applications== One commercial application of supercooling is in [[refrigeration]]. Freezers can cool drinks to a supercooled level<ref>[http://www.chillchamber.hussmann.com Chill Chamber] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090301174525/http://www.chillchamber.hussmann.com/ |date=March 1, 2009 }}</ref> so that when they are opened, they form a [[slush]]. Another example is a product that can supercool the beverage in a conventional freezer.<ref>[http://www.slush-it.com Slush-It!] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100123161644/http://www.slush-it.com/ |date=2010-01-23 }}</ref> [[The Coca-Cola Company]] briefly marketed special [[vending machine]]s containing [[Sprite (soft drink)|Sprite]] in the UK, and Coke in Singapore, which stored the bottles in a supercooled state so that their content would turn to [[Slush (beverage)|slush]] upon opening.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/gadgetlab/2007/09/coca-cola-plans/|title=Coca Cola Plans High Tech, Super Cool Sprite|author=Charlie Sorrel|website=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]|publisher=[[Condé Nast]]|date=2007-09-21|accessdate=2013-12-05}}</ref>
Supercooling was successfully applied to organ preservation at Massachusetts General Hospital/[[Harvard Medical School]]. [[Liver]]s that were later transplanted into recipient animals were preserved by supercooling for up to 96 hours (4 days), quadrupling the limits of what could be achieved by conventional liver preservation methods. The livers were supercooled to a temperature of –6 °C in a specialized solution that protected against freezing and injury from the cold temperature.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Berendsen |first1=TA |last2=Bruinsma |first2=BG |last3=Puts |first3=CF |last4=Saeidi |first4=N |last5=Usta |first5=OB |last6=Uygun |first6=BE |first7=Maria-Louisa |last7=Izamis |first8=Mehmet |last8=Toner |first9=Martin L |last9=Yarmush |first10= Korkut |last10=Uygun |title=Supercooling enables long-term transplantation survival following 4 days of liver preservation |journal=Nature Medicine |year=2014 |volume=20 |issue=7 |pages=790–793 |doi=10.1038/nm.3588|pmid=24973919 |pmc=4141719 }}</ref>
Another potential application is drug delivery. In 2015 researchers demonstrated the ability to crystallize membranes at a specific time. Liquid-encapsulated drugs can potentially be delivered to the site and with a slight environmental change, the liquid rapidly changes into a crystalline form that releases the drug.<ref>{{cite news|title= A "super cool" way to deliver drugs |first=George |last=Hunka|date=2015-05-06 |accessdate= |url=http://www.rdmag.com/news/2015/05/super-cool-way-deliver-drugs |publisher=R&D}}</ref>
In 2016 a team at [[Iowa State University]] proposed a method for "soldering without heat" by using encapsulated droplets of supercooled liquid metal to repair heat sensitive electronic devices.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cen.acs.org/articles/94/i11/Soldering-without-heat.html|title=Soldering without heat|author=Mitch Jacoby|website=Chemical and Engineering News|date=2016-03-14|accessdate=2016-03-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nature.com/articles/srep21864|title=Mechanical Fracturing of Core-Shell Undercooled Metal Particles for Heat-Free Soldering|author=Simge Çınar, Ian D. Tevis, Jiahao Chen & Martin Thuo|website=Nature|date=2016-02-23|accessdate=2016-03-14}}</ref>
Eftekhari et al. proposed an empirical theory explaining that supercooling of ionic [[liquid crystal|liquid crystals]] can build ordered channels for diffusion for energy storage applications. In this case, the electrolyte has a rigid structure comparable with that of a solid electrolyte but the diffusion coefficient can be as large as in liquid electrolytes. Supercooling increases the medium viscosity but keeps the directional channels open for diffusion.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Eftekhari |first1=A |last2=Liu |first2=Y |last3=Chen |first3=P |title=Different roles of ionic liquids in lithium batteries |journal=Journal of Power Sources |year=2016 |volume=334 |pages=221–239 |doi=10.1016/j.jpowsour.2016.10.025|bibcode=2016JPS...334..221E }}</ref>
==See also== *[[Amorphous solid]] *[[Pumpable ice technology]] *[[Subcooling]] *[[Ultracold atom]] *[[Viscous liquid]] *[[Freezing rain]]

E. |title=Supercooled and Glassy Water |journal=[[Physics Today]] |volume=56 |issue=6 |pages=40–46 |year=2003 |url=http://polymer.bu.edu/hes/articles/ds03.pdf |doi=10.1063/1.1595053 |ref=harv|bibcode = 2003PhT....56f..40D }} *{{cite journal |last=Giovambattista |first=N. | last2 = Angell | first2 = C. ''[[Thermogutta terrifontis|T terrifontis]]'' | synonyms = }} '''''Thermogutta''''' is a [[thermophilic]] genus of bacteria from the family of [[Planctomycetaceae]].{{cite journal |title=Thermogutta |journal=www.uniprot.org |url=https://www.uniprot.org/taxonomy/1676125 |language=en}}{{cite journal |last1=Parker |first1=Charles Thomas |last2=Garrity |first2=George M |title=Taxonomic Abstract for the genera. |journal=The NamesforLife Abstracts |date=1 January 2003 |doi=10.1601/tx.26395 |language=en}}{{cite journal |last1=Slobodkina |first1=GB |last2=Kovaleva |first2=OL |last3=Miroshnichenko |first3=ML |last4=Slobodkin |first4=AI |last5=Kolganova |first5=TV |last6=Novikov |first6=AA |last7=van Heerden |first7=E |last8=Bonch-Osmolovskaya |first8=EA |title=Thermogutta terrifontis gen. nov., sp. nov. and Thermogutta hypogea sp. nov., thermophilic anaerobic representatives of the phylum Planctomycetes. |journal=International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology |date=March 2015 |volume=65 |issue=Pt 3 |pages=760–5 |doi=10.1099/ijs.0.000009 |pmid=25479950}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Taxonbar}} [[Category:Bacteria genera]] {{Bacteria-stub}}
